original_title: Sri Lanka’s shares edge down in mid day trade
original_body_lines: ECONOMYNEXT – Sri Lanka’s shares edged down in mid day trade, on thin volumes as the market experiences selling pressures and profit taking, an analyst said.

“The market is down as the selling trend continues, as there is a price decline in all shares across the board, combined with the month ending followed by margin calls,” Ranjan Ranatunga of First Capital Holdings said.
All Share Price Index (ASPI) was down  0.92 percent or 30.34 points to 9,199.94, the most liquid index S&P SL20 was down 1.13 percent or 30.34 points to 2,647.47.
The market generated a slow turnover of 47o million rupees during 1130 hours.
“Yesterday market closed at low and thin trading revenue, which we are expecting for today aswell,” Ranatunga said.

The main contributor to turnover is Lanka IOC, over news of that Sri Lanka cabinet has granted approval for three oil companies from China, the United States, and Australia in collaboration with Shell Pl to lease 150 fuel station for each company to operate in local market, Minister of Energy Kanchana Wijesekera said.
Index heavy shares and retail favorites were between the top losers during mid day trade, top losers were Vallibel Finance, John Keells Holdings and Browns Investment. (Colombo/Mar28/2023)
